The Good. Started using coinbase as my first exchange last year. Loved the app for training and the coins it gave for free. It was easy to use. 
The Bad.  I recently noticed that the rate for selling my assets is never as higher as the rate for buying AT THE SAME TIME. At first I was a novice and thought this was normal with crypto. Now that I use multiple exchanges, I learned it isn‚Äôt true. This time I was smarter and did a screenshot. Under ‚ÄúHome‚Äù the rate was $5.04, when I went to sell, the sell rate was $5.02...I backed out and went to buy, the buy rate was $5.06 (the rate shown on all the other exchanges btw), I went back again to sell and it was at $5.01, all the while Home and Portfolio said $5.04. 
I searched the support page for an explanation...Nothing. Emailed the company...no response. Usually they are very response. 
Now I see they are going public. $.05 difference being retained without explanation on assets is suspicious to me. It concerns me. 
And no this was not the gas fee; it was the listed rate. 
All have started moving all of my assets to other exchanges that have proven more reliable to me after testing small amounts.

I try contacting support to clarify things but they keep saying I need to submit additional ID like a passport. I try explaining that their website tells me I've already passed verification to the highest level and it won't let me submit anything else. They've stopped responding to my emails now. Why do I even need to submit my passport or additional ID? Am I just supposed to take a picture of my passport and email it to them?  Who does that?

First issue: So you can move money from your bank account to your USD wallet in Coinbase without fees. However, your bank transfers it and it‚Äôs gone immediately and Coinbase sits on it for 5-7 days, before it shows up in your wallet. Im sure they are collecting interest in your money before they move it to your account.

Second issue: When you do have a funded USD wallet and try to use it to buy digital currency, at least bitcoin cash, you are not allowed to chose your USD wallet to purchase be digital currency with. The app forces you to either choose bank account or credit card, with the higher fees for both. Why can you not choose the funds you already have deposited with them?

Third issue: If you choose to use a bank account to buy digital currency, then once again you wait 7 days for the purchase to be made. With the volatility of digital currency, this make Coinbase and obsolete tool.

You can use your USD wallet to trade with GDAX, but if your not buying that way, there is zero point using Coinbase.

For me the hunt continues for a digital currency wallet that actually works, makes sense, and isn't a rip off.

I set up a new account, got verified, funded it with funds from my bank account, and purchased my first bitcoin in less than a hour. Login problems, which meant I couldn‚Äôt buy or sell in critical times, problems when trying to select which account I want to use for payment will disappear or won‚Äôt load extremely buggy. Turning off the vpn solved the network connection issue. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-

Since Nov 8, 2022, the app stopped working with the message ‚ÄòWe are having network connection issues.‚Äô I made sure my iPhone is on the latest iOS and deleted the Coinbase app, and reinstalled it multiple times, but nothing corrected the behavior. Coinbase claims it's working on the status app page, but it is not.

Starting with the good,  you have a multitude of tradeable cryptocurrency, customer service is quick to respond to your issue, and it is fairly simple to navigate the app.  

The cons that I have notice is that you are limited to how much you can invest at once(this may be a security feature for the company), there is more than a 2% spread when you convert your coins resulting in a dramatic loss in fiat currency(where the company states it can be more or less than 2% spread depending on some factors), and the same goes for investing into the coins($1000 with a $14 fee somehow became $980 instantly).

I recommend investing your money, wait for a good time to withdraw, and continue on that path.

I personally find other apps better and more clear but since I have money tied up in this app and the customer service is good I will ride it out for now.

Downloaded CoinBase & purchased currency using my Credit Card.
A few days later, the credit card I used wasn't listed as a payment method. I went to add it again and was asked to verify my identity with my license. I added my license and it told me it would take 3-5 minutes to verify. Several hours later, I was denied for an "unknown reason." I tried several times more, and I received the same error message.
My friend downloaded the app several days after me and went to verify her identity using her license and a selfie (which I was NEVER asked to upload). Within a couple hours, she was approved with a massive weekly limit. I tried again, and was denied again. 
These ID verifications are only going through for certain people, and it's completely unfair.

Don‚Äôt use this app expecting to be able to buy when there is a dip in the rate or sell when it is going up. This is especially true with the apps so called ‚Äúalerts‚Äù, which should more accurately be called ‚ÄúHa ha! You missed it, but the staff got it‚Äù. I have literally been on the page and gotten multiple alerts one of the coins was dropping below or above a threshold I had set yet it was impossible for me to buy as when I went to process the payment it is what it was before the dip or rise. Often times these mythical rise and falls then don‚Äôt even show up in the charts as a high or low. 

The app has often been unavailable during peak volumes for ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù upgrades.

You also can not have the app default to making purchases from your wallet instead of a bank account. So I need to keep changing that manually (and then the dollar value you planned to buy/sell is set to $0 again).

This app might be fine for an occasional sale or purchase. But with the long time delays between notification and actual price changes and there being so many false notifications it is more frustrating than useful.

I wish I would‚Äôve been paying attention to all these other complaints about Coinbase tying up our money and just holding it. I sent $15k there via direct connect from my bank account. I‚Äôve been using CoinBase for over a year and have noticed discrepancies in the amount that I should have after a trade and the amount that actually ends up in my account.

Today I called them to ask about it. I explained my situation to the customer support representative, showed him the numbers and transaction reference, and did the math for him (which was ~3% of the total amount).

He said this kind of thing happens and it probably has to do with transaction fees. I responded that the confirmation page during the transaction said there was a $0.00 transaction fee. He said ‚Äúthere may be other fees or something.‚Äù

After calmly explaining that I can accept fees or differences if the price changes during the trade, but I need to see something that confirms where my money is going, he said he would have to escalate my issue to someone else and they would email me when they are able.

TL:DR
3% of my transaction disappeared, no trace. CoinBase said they don't know what happened BUT they can send me an email.

Never keep your money in an exchange long-term. They are not your friends, they are not your partners. They are just yet another type of bank and until you move your money into your own offline wallet you are implicitly trusting them not to shaft you.

Treat Coinbase as you would a back alley exchange in a second world country: get in, do your business, then get the heck out and don't leave a dime there.

Years ago, the IRS determined Bitcoin to be a capital asset, meaning that gains & losses from buying & selling BTC are required to be reported on Schedule D of your income tax return 1040. Last I heard, Coinbase still does not provide you with a 1099-B showing your trades and their profit/loss, or show on their site your average cost basis. For BTC investors who do regular automatic purchases, and then take partial profits, filling out the IRS-required paperwork is very time-consuming. Coinbase should at least permit export of trade data in an IRS-friendly schedule D-like format. Otherwise, they lose market share to brokers like Robinhood who provide 1099-B forms for their customers.

Not to diminish the usefulness of Coinbase as a Bitcoin broker, there are three things I want to be seeing if I‚Äôm paying such large fees.

1) Recurring buys for all assets offered by Coinbase.
2) Recurring deposits to coinbase USD wallet (this should be a no-brainer).
3) Customer-designed indices; i.e. if I want to make my own custom Coinbase bundle with a 70% weighting in BTC and a 30% weighting in ETH, it should be possible to execute a buy order just like the Coinbase bundle. How revolutionary! And what about recurring buys for the Coinbase bundle, too? Why can‚Äôt I just set and forget my crypto buys instead of dropping big chunks all at once?

Pro‚Äôs

- Good education 
- Provides more transparency on the transaction details than other platforms like Gemini

Con‚Äôs
- This is a big one: I made a trade when a coin I wanted reached a certain low.  Coinbase made the trade at greater than $1.00 than was possible according chart at the time of my trade. - High transaction fees per trade

For an experience, I bought $250 worth Bitcoin when the price was low at around $34k and sold it @$36k, but made no profit at all. 

Because of: 
- Super expensive fees: you are charged a fee when you buy coins and sell them back and they are ridiculously high
- Big ‚Äúspread‚Äù: Coin prices are Higher than actual market price when you buy them and lower than actual market price when you sell them. in other words Coinbase makes profit out of your transaction in addition to the percentage fees, which are already high.
- To withdraw your money you have to wait almost a week. They say it is to prevent the fraud activities. But putting money into their account is immediate.
- They want your bank account login and password via Plaid, so you have to disclose your actual e-banking credentials.

The app is overall simple to get used to and the educational videos help out tremendously. The only major fall back is Coinbase does not keep track of your profits or losses . You need to keep track of how much you invested and whether or not you lost or gained from your investment. I thought this would have been a standard feature but it‚Äôs not. This would really setup  Coinbase to be a more robust investment tool and would keep more of its clientele for the long term.
